As a parent of a child who player football (since age 7) and baseball and basketball.  You can get hurt in any sport.  Football because of the contact can cause a lot of injuries.  Baseball,  a line drive can hit you in the head or if you pitch the ball could hit you in the face.  Basketball, you could fall and hit your head.  Anything could happen in any of these sports.  How do you as a parent stop your child from doing what they love .  I don't mean to sound mean but I don't think it is anyone fault when it comes to injuries.  When my child played I knew what could happen but just didn't think about it and let him go.  This is just from my experience.  God bless those who have lost their love ones from sports.

I am not a lawyer, nor am I versed in real estate law.  However, the use of "condemnation" (the seizure, as of property, for public use) seems inappropriate here.  This sounds more like a right of way, which is "an easement that allows another person to travel or pass through your land. The most common form of right of way easement is a road or path through your land. The right of way easement road is meant to benefit a particular person or another parcel of land not owned by you."  If beachgoers have been using the driveway to access the beach for decades, then the right-of-way in many, many cases throughout the US have been considered 'grandfathered' in, even though no formal right-of-way or easement existed.

Why do we need official or government sponsored apprenticeship programs?  In my teens and twenties, I went from work site to work site, and from craftsman to craftsman, until I picked up skills and references.  However, many trade guilds and unions already have apprenticeship programs.  I could have gotten into a 4 year apprenticeship program with the sheet metal workers union back in the 70s. First year apprentices were making more than twice minimum wage, but it was very hard labor, not like working as a barrister at a Starbucks.

Thank you for this thoughtful piece.  Alaska cannot afford to ignore that unusual weather patterns across the Arctic amount to evidence of a changing climate.  Frighteningly, these patterns are what scientists thought might happen towards the end of this century, not in the first quarter.  Sustainability of salmon, as waters warm, and caribou, as we get more ice in winter, will impact Alaskans from north to south.  We must protect our lands, waters and air from the combined impacts of both carbon pollution and other contaminants.  The EPA should aid with this, and a scientist  should be chosen to lead this agency, not a science denier.  A scientist can advise our elected officials to make reasonable policies that protect the environment in support of development, avoiding leaving the public with enormous bills to clean up contaminated sites across our state and country.  Thank you for considering this suggestion, Senators Murkowski and Sullivan.

To single out Catholic persons or organizations is incoherent, unjust, and should never be done.

kag - who is to pay if they get sick, if anyone gets sick with a life threatening illness?  the point of insurance is the spread the risk.  If we spread the risk among all people, then the average any one pays is no more than the fair share of all the expenses.  In other words, rather than one person being financially ruined by ill health - the point of insurance - the cost is spread among everyone.  Break this down into smaller groups and the risk of catastrophic costs hitting someone in that group rises; when that happens that groups premiums skyrocket.  More, put "healthy" people in one group and "unhealthy" people in another group, and it is a foregone conclusion which group will have higher expenses.  

By the way, I am also on Medicare and find it good.  I do have a Medicare Supplement plan; I have to hope my finances hold up so I can keep it.  If I can't it would not take long for a serious illness to deplete the rest of my assets.

I think you need to look at your policy costs with a sharper eye towards detail.  It is the comprehensive and collision rates here that drive up the cost of insurance, not the liability.  Comprehensive coverage costs are driven by claims from road hazards, such as deer and potholes, and the costs of repairing/replacing damage due to hail.  Collision coverage costs are tied to the replacement value of your chosen vehicle. Today's cars are totaled by hail which would not have damaged a vehicle built in the 1950s or 1960s at all. The gauge of metal in your vehicle today is much less because lighter vehicles go further on a gallon of fuel. That thinner metal is also likely to result in more extensive damage in a collision, which results in a higher repair bill and a greater chance the vehicle will be a total loss after a collision.

If you believe your auto insurance costs too high, thank the federal government and its regulations for finding yet another way to pick your pocket.

It's important to read that naive NYT article carefully. It references a German anti-coal activist group's numbers, as well as muddling them with a second group's semi-annually updated global coal-fired power plant database.

That latter (http://endcoal.org/global-coal-plant-tracker/) is interesting, and was updated in July 2017. It lists 584 coal-fired power plants under construction globally with a planned nameplate capacity of 290 GW. (Not all of these will be completed.) It also lists 968 planned coal-fired plants that were shelved (588 GW capacity), 1286 that were cancelled outright (897 GW capacity), and 1456 that were retired (202 GW capacity).

The relationships discussed in this article to birth and adopted countries and between those who remain and those who emigrate to the US described will be familiar to many Canadians who have close relatives that have moved to the US on a permanent basis (and, conversely, for many former Canadians living in the US).  

Arguably, the divisions between people in question are overdone in too many cases and create an unnecessary barrier between those who leave and those who stay in Canada.  Focusing inordinately on these differences also serves to obscure the obvious advantage to all people in the US and Canada arising from the existence of two countries and therefore two choices of society that share the North American ethos and much else in common but exist with different political, social and institutional frameworks and scale.

My unambiguous choice is to live in Canada but I see no reason to assume that all Canadians share (or should share) my preference.

If you over simplify, as I think Ms. Hayes has, it's pretty plain. No one person, president, senator, congressman, etc, can overturn an amendment to our Constitution. However, any right protected by an amendment can be modified as has been done many times in the past through judicial fiat. So to flesh out the concerns of Second Amendment people, should supreme court justices resign during the next administration, and judges placed into that court who oppose the Heller decision, it is quite likely that gun control advocates will file suits that will go all the way to the supreme court and the court will reverse itself. The right to keep and bear arms will then become a collective rather than an individual right.

Judging by the Comments on health care articles in the last few months, Canadians no longer believe that our health care is the best in the world. Another myth which needs attention is the cost of health care in the private sector. That is plain silly. One has a choice of health care. Just as in car, house or life insurance one selects the quality of health care desired. There is no need to select and pay for the level chosen by gov't. 

Another huge advantage of health care in the private sector is that the taxpayer no longer pays for those who are able to pay themselves. US data would suggest that is about 83% of the population. An 83% reduction in cost to the taxpayer. About 17% of Canadians would need taxpayer help. 

So cost would be under the control of individual Canadians just like food and housing and whatever. No periodic cost of health care discussions. Health care would be just another part of our individual lives. Individuals select cost.

This ruling should come as no surprise, given the US approach to trade, the environment in which it is made and NAFTA renegotiations. We would do well to look to the what next. There are a few scenarios.
 
BBD will not ship to Delta until tariffs are dropped (unless Delta is willing to pay them) which means shuffling its delivery schedule and finding other buyers. I understand the latter is in the works.

Canada will launch NAFTA and WTO challenges. The US will prolong a WTO process for years. The US will not agree to dispute resolution under NAFTA arguing technicalities.

The tariffs may be part of a NAFTA deal bit I doubt it. Canada will resist its use as a bargaining chip. The US is unlikely to drop it without concessions.

The US will eventually reduce but not eliminate the duties. BBD will not ship to the US, ever, since it can sell to the world instead.

Overall the big losers are American airlines that will not have access to these very competitive aircraft.

When the marijuana for medical purposes should not be used according to Health Canada 

Cannabis should not be used if you:

are under the age of 25
are allergic to any cannabinoid or to smoke
have serious liver, kidney, heart or lung disease
have a personal or family history of serious mental disorders such as schizophrenia, psychosis, depression, or bipolar disorder
are pregnant, are planning to get pregnant, or are breast-feeding
are a man who wishes to start a family
have a history of alcohol or drug abuse or substance dependence
Talk to your health care practitioner if you have any of these conditions. There may be other conditions where this product should not be used, but which are unknown due to limited scientific information.

Now ask how many Canadians know these contraindications for use. The idea that this drug with this profile would become a legal product is insane.

The suggestion for members to divert all tithe to local church budget, would impact local church operations because it would shut-off the flow of funds not only to the GC but to local and union conferences as well.

Believe it or not, but most local conference expenditures directly benefit the local churches and their members.  For example local conferences fund 100% of the salaries and benefits for pastors, as well as a substantial % for church school teachers.  Local conferences also operate academies, summer camps, etc, on behalf of all of the members.

Likewise, union conferences operate colleges and revolving funds and some other services that directly benefit local churches and schools and members.

I am not saying all of these layers are necessary.  I am saying that most of the services they provide are useful to local churches and schools and members.

It always seems easier after a big market move to the upside. Easy to make money. And then when your solid / great investments are down 30% or more, what do you do? How do you decide what to do? If you have a plan, you know exactly what to do. If you have no written plan, you're forced to guess. You have a choice: knowing what to do, always knowing,  or guessing what to do. Sooner or later you will hold an investment that is imploding.  

If you have a written plan, an IPS, you can use it to make the right decisions at all times, even when under extreme levels of stress.  Otherwise, you will likely make stressful and losing decisions.     

In short plan first, invest later. If you want to win.

The idea of what marriage is has changed drastically over the last fifty or so years.  For many centuries, marriage was a business contract between two families; love wasn't part of the equation.  Moreover, women were treated like property.  A woman had to submit to her husband.  It wasn't until the 1870s that abuse was considered a crime.  We didn't start seriously prosecuting it in the US until the 1970s.  Marital rape didn't exist as a crime until well into the 20th century.  A woman in the 1950s probably had little recourse when dealing with an abusive husband; now she has many more options.

I'm old enough to remember when DST was first introduced during WW2. For the first few years it was year-round. During the winter months the school start-time changed from 9:00 to 9:30 so we elementary school children could walk to school in daylight. (I grew up in Winnipeg.)

The primary reason tuition has skyrocketed to absurd levels is because of the reliance upon third party funding.  If all or even most students had only their own money to use when shopping for a college, the financial landscape would look radically different.  Not much different than how the housing bubble was inflated by third parties loaning absurd amounts of money to individuals who had no hope of ever paying it back.

The notion that everyone must go to college, combined with loans that permit anyone to temporarily afford tuition they would otherwise never remotely consider, has driven faculty and administrator salaries and other expenditures ever skyward, as without facing the real limits on demand they have no incentive to control costs.  True demand at these price points is being distorted by the reliance upon risky loans.  The resulting bubble will most certainly burst, as even now the cost/benefit ratio of a college education is becoming pretty dicey for many.

The biggest problem with an increase in defense spending is that most of the money would go to foreigners producing the equipment needed. Decades of neglect of sovereign defense industrial capabilities have reduced Canada to a status below that of much smaller countries such as Norway and Sweden and reduced the federal government to beg a foreign and largely subsidized military contractor (Boeing) not to cause grief to the last global industrial, Canadian-owned company (Bombardier). If the federal government and the military brass had acted in a similar manner as their counterparts in other countries, we would have a much more resilient Defense & Aerospace sector with the high-value added jobs coming with it. To change this will take many years and may require Canada to align more closely with other countries than the US. Australia, which procured a complete fleet of subs recently, comes to mind.

Harassment is so widespread across the public service it cannot be fixed internally. People are regularly intimidated and bullied into going against ethics and proper conduct by superiors who are untouchable because they are protected by a special employment law for the public service, and internal processes do not protect the employees at lower levels. This is done on purpose for government to function without anyone questioning orders from the top. Keeps government going, but crates a very bad working environment.

Even if Ottawa start a process with the intention to end these practices, and it did several times with no positive results to show for, it will fail once again, unless it applies the private sector laws to its employees, and allow them to press charges against their superiors and challenge them in court, which is likely to result in names being tarnished and the abusers being fired. Only then will bullying and harassment stop in the public service.

Switzerland uses the "polluters pay principle" Bin bags (for municipal solid waste) are taxed with pay-per-bag fees in three quarters of the communes (and the recycling rate doubled in twenty years). An alternative idea that is used by another great recycling country of Sweden, uses the  extended producer responsibility (EPR) which seeks to shift the responsibility of dealing with waste from governments (and thus, taxpayers and society at large) to the entities producing it. In effect, it internalised the cost of waste disposal into the cost of the product, theoretically meaning that the producers will improve the waste profile of their products, thus decreasing waste and increasing possibilities for reuse and recycling. So if you want to make cheap items that serve one purpose, they can, but it's going to cost them a lot more than making ones that are recyclable. Switzerland currently has a 60% recycling rate.

It is not a "narrow technical interpretation".  The Crown stays charges when it does not have enough evidence to have a reasonable hope of getting a conviction.  If a person is not convicted, there is nothing "narrow" or "technical" about his innocence.  The staying of charges does not imply "the very real possibility that the very guilty do occasionally beat the charges".  Canada's laws do not provide for incarcerating people because of the possibility that they may be guilty -- except if they are charged and awaiting trial -- and certainly not for incarcerating them on a pretext that has nothing to do with the crime of which they may possibly be guilty.

The fundamental problem here is that we have two parallel systems of justice. One is a real justice system, with law enforcement investigators, courts, attorneys, judges, juries, and established law and procedures and sanctions that have been worked through over time. We have skilled and experienced and licensed people doing this very difficult work of criminal justice. In cases of sexual assault involving young people, usually involving alcohol, usually occurring in private, involving questions of consent, the cases are especially difficult to decide fairly. 

The other system of essentially criminal justice is housed in our universities. This has been forced on the universities by the Civil Rights Office of the Department of Education and its broad interpretation of Title IX. It is a makeshift system that must--whenever a mention of sexual assault is even overheard--conduct an investigation, reach a decision, and enforce sanctions. Universities are manifestly unfit for these tasks.

Technically, you are correct in that Premier Two Moms approval could be 0% but if voters decide to hold their noses and vote Liberal regardless then they would win.

Historically, however, you are decidedly out to lunch.  

Usually, there is a strong correlation between the approval rating % for the party leader and the vote % the party winds up receiving.

With 3 relatively strong major parties in Ontario, it is possible for one to win a majority with 36-39% of the vote.

But no party can win a majority or even a minority if they stand at 16% in the polls and no party whose leader at election time stands at 16% in the polls will pull more than 24-25% of the vote (usually within 5 points of 16%).

If you have a persuasive argument otherwise, I would be fascinated to hear it.

P.S.  Take her greater public sector supporters out of the equation and Wynne-Bag is now at about 10% .   And we could be even worse off is the NDP aka The Notoriously Dumb Party takes the trougher vote and wins

The Alaska Supreme Court's decision that Permanent Fund dividends are not an entitlement from a dedicated fund but an appropriation issue supports the approach by Mr. Bradner. Using what we have first before enacting new taxes is the approach of a good steward. Sadly, many people treat the PFD as an entitlement despite the court's decision that is firmly based on our state constitution. Because of this attitude, those same people consider a smaller appropriation for the PFD as a "taking."  However, the PFD is an expenditure of state funds and that use of state funds must compete and be balanced against all other needs. A smaller PFD is not a taking, but should be the result of a careful and thoughtful process by the governor and the legislature to meet state needs from a smaller treasury.

I don't know what to say about civility, but compromise is, in my opinion, a rare condition usually only brought about in the face of imminent disaster. Take, for instance, the recent conclusion of the legislature. The budget passed, and now signed, could be called a compromise of sorts, but it does nothing to address the State's dire financial crisis. I'm not agreeing with one side or the other as far as 'fixes' are concerned, but I'm just pointing out that it took to impending disaster (opinion) of state shutdown to bring a budget to the governor. 
This seems grim. However, I have some faith yet that people of all persuasions can and will do what's right when the time comes. Americans have reliably done so for 200 years (minus that 1860 incident) and I trust they will into the future. Until then, *civil* disagreement is okay, and part and parcel of a healthy democracy.(yes, I know, a republic, with the representatives popularly elected, so, a form of democracy.)

You are correct.  Most of  the words of the Courts and Military are of French extraction because the Norman conquerors ruled them.  The animals in the fields tended by the Anglo Saxon serfs still have Anglo-Saxon names cow, sheep, pig etc but the choice food on the table that the Normans saw have French names, beef, steak, mouton, porc , fillet, etc .  The poorer cuts still  have the English names.  French was the official language of the Courts, the Administration, the Royal Court, the land , the church (with Latin) until a Coronation in the 13th Century when  for the first time in 200 years the language used was English.    English survived not because  of language police but because the people wanted it to and they weren't  afraid to incorporate large amounts of the French, Swedish, Danish, German, Latin,  into it. Even words from India.

Minimum wage is a tool to control inflation. Minimum wage jobs are not meant to be a career choice. 
Minimum wage controls inflation by controlling demand.  Hopefully, most people understand the basic law of supply and demand. Simply put, as demand increases, price increases. By increasing minimum wage, you temporarily increase the buying power of minimum wage recipients. As those people enter the market looking to spend their windfall, demand obviously increases. Suffice it to say, so does the price of those items in demand. Now, those people end up right back to where they were before, unable to afford what they want. The the cries for increasing minimum wage begin again and everyone forgets why prices increased in the first place.
To that end, raising minimum wage does nothing to help those who it targets.
Minimum wage jobs are for students and people looking to supplement their income for extra spending money, not as primary support.

"To begin with, Plos One, the online journal of the original article, requires authors to pay for publication, as a type of vanity press. Even if that scholarship turned out to be solid ..."

When Oppegaard calls PLoS  One a vanity press, he does it and the scientific community a grave disservice.  PLoS One is one of the first open access journals, which was established, in part, to counteract high-profile cases of fraud in biomedical research.  The Wikipedia entry for open access (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_access#History) has this:

"In 2001, 34,000 scholars around the world signed "An Open Letter to Scientific Publishers", calling for "the establishment of an online public library that would provide the full contents of the published record of research and scholarly discourse in medicine and the life sciences in a freely accessible, fully searchable, interlinked form". Scientists signing the letter also pledged not to publish in or peer-review for non-open access journals."

The GRT is really just anpother sales tax that will be passed on to the consumers by the corporations.  

Unlike a 'real' sales tax, however, there are no exemptions for food, medicine, health care, or other necessities of life.

It will therefore be a regressive tax which will hit the poor harder.  

Gasoline will go up in cost.  Groceries will go up in cost.  Prescriptions will go up in cost.  Medical costs will go up.  

Those things are all provided primarily by large corporations who won't have to worry about competitive disadvantage between others in their particular industry.

This is a form of social welfare.  As such, it will be burdened by administrative costs, complexity and social stigma, a burden to be avoided.

Instead, If all adults received monthly benefits (say $600 per month to begin, taxed as employment income) under an universal Federal/Provincial program funded by a revenue neutral progressive income tax and redistribute program, then

people would receive basic income on a steady basis by right but would be able to continue generating their own income from other sources without implications of shame or pointed incentives to cheat the system, 
the economy and society generally would benefit from a reduction of current trends for income and wealth gaps to grow or for lost purchasing power when unemployment or underemployment rises, and
social service programs could be fine-tuned and streamlined to focus attention increasingly on the non-income needs of people.

The announced program should proceed but hopefully, evolve into the above proposal.

"Hebrew women were not allowed to divorce their husbands, but could be divorced for anything from burning the dinner (Hillel) to adultery (Shammai). Sludge takes a long time to build up - encouraged by not changing oil and filter at the recommended intervals. Turbos are especially sensitive. Oil and filter changes well within recommended intervals are cheap engine insurance. Also buy oil filters from a reputable source such as FRAM - not the OEM versions which I have found to be largely ineffective.
I do my own to ensure proper high quality oil and efficient filters - saves tiome and money. Engines should last > 250,000Km these days without burning oil or loosing pressure.

The biggest issue I have is that there's nothing compelling people to get training on how to handle a weapon,  We can talk all we want about responsible gun ownership but the world is choc full of irresponsible people who buy a gun and stick it in their pocket without any training or practice.  There needs to be some extensive training if you plan to carry a gun in public, a weekend NRA course and a few boxes of ammo at the range won't cut it.   

As someone who owns many firearms the first thing I acknowledge is that guns are really dangerous.  The only thing that negates the danger is deeply seated respect for the damage my weapons can do, vigilance against complacency, knowledge of safe handling, and lots of regular practice.

I'd also add that the selection of a firearm for personal defense is less important than the actual practice and training, there's a million good choices for a defensive pistol but the most effective gun in the world is the one you train with.

Whether one is for or against the renaming of Lane County it's crucial to check in to the fascinating historical question of whether Lane owned slaves. This refers to Peter Waldo, a black boy who had lived with Lane from about the time he was two, having been placed there by the court when he was an orphan in 1864.
You'll find a great piece of historical research at http://id.mind.net/~truwe/tina/waldo.html
An interesting newspaper item from Nov. 1878 reported on Waldo, now about 16/17, being sent to the pen for theft:
 "Peter Waldo is a native of Douglas County, and is a descendant, on the mother's side, of African parents. He was raised and cared for by Gen. Jos. Lane until the old gentleman could control him no longer, since which time he has been on the "ragged edge" almost continually."
Shortly before Lane died in 1881  he sent a note to his old friend James Nesmith which  requested  Nesmith "see that he [Waldo] gets work of some honorable character" when released from the pen.

It's way too early to say what Taggart will accomplish in recruiting as Oregon's new head football coach. But he is definitely taking a very different approach from that of Helfrich or Kelly. Taggart seems more hands on, and more aware of how to use social media to connect to and establish rapport with recruits. By contrast, Helfrich and Kelly seemed more "traditional", but over time, especially in the last few seasons, that approach wasn't working as well anymore.

As for recruiting QBs specifically, I think Taggart has a good track record. When he was the running backs coach under Jim Harbaugh at Stanford, he helped to recruit Andrew Luck, who was a pro-style QB. At his last stop, University of South Florida, Taggart recruited and developed Quinton Flowers into a dual-threat QB running a prolific offense. The most obvious need for Ducks recruiting is defense. Taggart needs more defensive play-makers, like Jabril Peppers of Michigan and Jonathan Allen of Alabama... holiday wish list!

I find it interesting that Roserberg finds the market expensive but likes energy due to significant profit margin growth due to higher energy prices.

If you look at the current P/E of the market, it is heavily skewed by energy companies (the S&P500 energy sub index has a P/E of 139X) because their earnings are significantly depressed.  You could argue that they are pretty much the biggest reason why this market looks expensive (you also have expensive utilities and consumer staples and other "safe havens").  

Yes, at these oil prices, earnings from energy companies are set to expand meaningfully.  But not anywhere close to where they were in 2014 so keep that enthusiasm in check.  But still there is an argument for earnings from this sector to go from pretty much 0 to much higher than 0.  That brings down the market P/E.  

But if you focus on parts of the market outside of energy and the other "safe haven" sectors, you find a market that is still attractively valued.

To be clear, between Monroe and Lorane, historic Territorial Highway  IS the "Wine Trail".
There's even more  history here, as this is  also the path  of the ancient  California Trail, main route  south out of the Willamette Valley, and later an important wagon and stage road. And it has two local museums, South Benton County in Monroe and Crow-Applegate in Veneta .
This also the  north-south valley of the Long Tom (Lama Tam Buff) River and its main tributary Coyote Creek, which is fed by the many streams running off the Coast Range foothills. The local Long Tom Watershed Council is active in supporting a healthy ecosystem here.
There's a great new book by David Turner on this region, "Along the Long Tom River: Observations of the past and present" with  some nice vineyard photos.

Nonsense, another poster with a sanitised version of history. The problem with your assertion is that there was somehow a native way of life which stood in contrast with European society. There were thousands of very different native tribes, empires, regions, theocracies, kingdoms, fiefdoms, confederacies, etc in America prior to European arrival. Some were conquering, some built massive structures and large infrastructure works , others were nomadic. Many affected their environment and controlled it, changing local climates, deforestation, etc others did not. Most adapted to new technologies, whether horses or guns, etc, and modified their societies accordingly. Sadly, what they couldn't fight was germs and diseas, which wiped 90% of them out.

But to suggest their innovations and culture don't live on is silly. Plant domestication (corn, peppers, squash, tomtato, potato, etc), farming techniques , canoes/Kayaks, survival in the artic, modern constitutions, urban planning ideas, etc.

If the 6% IAP Contribution is directed to the Pension plan, and if the collective bargaining language requires the employer to provide a 6% pay increase.  Making this change would actually cost more than the current plan.

For example, if an employee is currently paid $1,000 a month the employer send $76.50 (7.65%) to FICA, about $220 (22%) to PERs pension and $60 (6%) to the IAP, so the employee costs the employer $1,357 for the month.  If the IAP contribution is redirected and the employee has to provide a 6% pay increase, the employee's month pay becomes $1,060, $81 (7.65%) goes to FICA, $297 (28%) goes to PERS pension, $0 goes to the IAP and the employee now costs the employer $1,438 for the month, an increase of $81.

Unless the employer's resource have increased, this change results in less services being able to be provided by the employer.

Over the years, DOD has fluctuated in Hawaii from being a good neighbor to being a bad neighbor to being a good neighbor, then a bad neighbor. But as we all know, base and mission commanders rotate through the islands on a short 1 or 2 year cycle, and have little to no institutional memory of problems or community concerns occurring prior to their arrival. Thus, longer-term residents suffer and pay a price in the form of pollution, noise, crowding, traffic jams near bases, and excessively high housing rental prices. DOD needs a better way to cycle their remedial efforts to offset these cyclical impacts. Where is the DOD Inspector General? Why cannot that office act to smooth out things? Red Hill Tanks? If they are playing chicken with the Democrats to see who will do the most damage to Oregon before giving in and being forced to take draconian measures, then that is just evil--and will make us more like Illinois.

We need some centrist politics from both sides. We need more give and take. The Republicans are the minority party, but they can stop the machinery on revenue reform, which they did. And that's extreme and destructive--and a waste of political power.

Renting isn't all negatives. My wife and I have been fortunate enough, either before we met, or after, to have responsible landlords. If something broke, they fixed it. In the case of our move to Englewood, we gave proper notice to our previous landlord, signed a new contract with our new landlord, arranged for movers, and we moved. No attorneys, no real estate brokers, no refinancing, etc.
So, like I said. Personal preference.

<I asked you whether the Law of the Land took precedence over the Law of God when they came into conflict.>
In a pluralistic society, governed by the principle of separation of church and state, the answer to that question is meaningless, useless, irrelevant.  The "Law of God" means different things to believers of different stripes, and nothing to non-believers. Civil law emerges from a process that allows everyone, believers and non-believers alike, to advocate their beliefs; but none of those beliefs is privileged in the legislative process, in the law, or in the enforcement of the law. When the requirements of the law genuinely conflict with the conscience of a citizen, that citizen enjoys the prerogative of engaging in civil disobedience -- but must expect to suffer the consequences of breaking the law.
